question.title: Shape
question.text: Is the galaxy simply smooth and rounded, with no sign of a disk?
question.help: The aim here is to divide featureless galaxies from all the rest. If you can see any interesting features at all, click "features or disk." Just occasionally you might see something that isn't a galaxy at all - the long streak of a satellite, for example, or a image swamped by light from a bright star. If this happens, just click "star or artifact". Click to see larger images.

question.title: Round
question.help: Not all galaxies are perfectly round - just look at the overall shape and put it in one of these three categories. If there's more than one galaxy in the field, remember always to concentrate on the one in the centre. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Bulge
question.text: Does the galaxy have a bulge at its centre?
question.help: Look at the centre of the galaxy - is there any sign of a bulge of stars sticking out above and below the otherwise smooth shape? If so, click yes.

question.title: Bar
question.text: Is there any sign of a bar feature through the centre of the galaxy?
question.help: Sometimes galaxies have a prominent straight "bar" running through their centre, and that's what we're looking for here. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Spiral
question.text: Is there any sign of a spiral arm pattern?
question.help: Look carefully for spiral arms - remember they may be embedded in the disk and not that easy to see. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Spiral
question.text: How tightly wound do the spiral arms appear?
question.help: Astronomers classify galaxies by how tight their arms are - you might find it easiest to see closest to the centre. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Spiral
question.text: How many spiral arms are there?
question.help: Some spiral galaxies are rather complicated, so don't be afraid to use the "more than 4" or "can't tell" buttons here.

question.title: Bulge
question.text: How prominent is the central bulge, compared with the rest of the galaxy?
question.help: It's not always easy to tell, but look at the centre of the galaxy for a round bulge of stars which may obscure any bar and the spiral arms in this central region. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Merger
question.text: Is the galaxy currently merging or is there any sign of tidal debris?
question.help: Now you can look at the larger picture - if the galaxy is colliding with another, click "merger." If there's no visible second system, but long streams of stars or gas are visible then click "tidal debris." "Both" and "Neither" are your other options. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Discuss
question.text: Would you like to discuss this object?
question.help: If you have any questions about this object, or think it may be interesting to others, or just have something to say, you can start a discussion on Talk by clicking "Yes". Talk will open in a new window - just close it to come back to the classification page.

question.title: Clumps
question.text: Does the galaxy have a mostly clumpy appearance?
question.help: Some galaxies are nothing but bright clumps. We don't mean those that have other features with a few small clusters of stars, but rather those that are made up mostly of bright clumps. Click to see larger images.

question.title: Clumps
question.help: Count the clumps! If there are more than 4, than don't worry about it - just click "more than 4."

question.title: Clumps
question.text: Do the clumps appear in a straight line, a chain, or a cluster?
question.help: Sometimes the clumps appear in a regular pattern - if so, then click the appropriate symbol.

question.title: Clumps
question.text: Is there one clump which is clearly brighter than the others?
question.help: Sometimes one clump dominates the scene. If so, click yes, otherwise, no.

question.title: Clumps
question.text: Is the brightest clump central to the galaxy?
question.help: For very clumpy galaxies it may be difficult to tell, but make your best guess whether that brightest clump lies at the centre of the system or not.

question.title: Symmetry
question.help: Are both halves of the galaxy the same? Or is one side disrupted or different in some way?

question.title: Clumps
question.text: Do the clumps appear to be embedded within a larger object?
question.help: Look carefully for faint background light surrounding the clumps - are they embedded in a visible galaxy?

question.title: Disk
question.text: Could this be a disk viewed edge-on?
question.help: Disc galaxies are very thin, so look different when viewed from the side. We're trying to find exactly edge-on galaxies with this question. If the galaxy looks needle-like, perhaps with a bulge at the centre, then click "yes," otherwise choose "no" (even for galaxies almost edge-on). Click to see larger images.
